document.text: Winchester.  William Madison Myers, a State highway engineer in charge of road work, died at his home here on thq thirty-ninth anniversary of his birth. He leaves three sisters and two brothers. Clifton Forge.All four of the col ored men implicated in the holdup here were given sentences of six months in jail, and fines of 25 each. The men attempted to hold up a white man. but he resisted and they fled. Roanoke.Dr. J. N. Lewis, leading physician here, and George Bernard, a Norfolk and Western Railroad office clerk, were killed when their auto mobile ran into a fence and was wrecked on the Hollis turnpike, five miles from this city. Lynchburg.  Judge George S. Stevens, of - this city, died Thursday at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. R. M. Thurman, in Bedford county. He was 82 years of age. Formerly he was judge of the Nelson County Court, after which he was clerk of the same court. He was a member of the Lov- ingston Methodist Church. Fredericksburg.  The Fredericks burg Va. Society of the Alumni of the University of Virginia will hold its annual meeting Saturday, April 13, Founders Day, at 8 P. M. In addition to business and social feat ures a banquet will be held and all ex-students of the university from Caroline, Stafford, Spotsylvania, King George counties and the city of Freder icksburg are invited to attend. Judge A. W. Wallace is president of the local alumni and Mr. B. P. Willis secretary and treasurer. Lynchburg.  Mrs. Annie Watson Mitchell died Wednesday night in Ap pomattox county, aged 63. She was well known for years as the proprie tor of the Buffalo Ridge Springs.

document.text: When we consider the area around us including all of the businesses and the different types of enterprises, it is hard to forget one prominent name. That Is SECURITY SCALES SERVICE INC. located at 4 Hickok Road in Lynchburg, phone 237-0111. They feature the best in scales such as Fairbanks, Electroscale,. Thurman and General. They offer this area service on all types of scales including Toledo. Through their efforts to provide the best in y d for this area,they have come to be known as part of the backbone to the structure of this area. From their beginning they have striven to provide the most up-do-date service, with friendly conscientious efforts. They supply our business and industry with the best in scales, thus aiding to the financial strength and growth of the area, and are recognized by both the businessman and the homeowner as an inseparable entity of our community. This company is responsible for pouring tens qf thousands of dollars back into this regions economy by supplying it with this vital product and service. The w riters of this 19 Review herein announce our complete recommendation to the management and individuals of this community minded company.

document.text: THOMAS H. THURMAN Thomas Herbert Thurman, 86 j of 1023 Rivermont Ave., died at f 255 p.m. Wednesday at Gug- genheimer Memorial Hospital. He was the husband of the late , Hennie North Thurman. Born in Appomattox County,  he was a son of Henry Clay Thurman and Maggie Carter , Thurman. He was a retired lo-  cal manager of Eastern Mutual Life Insurance Co. and a mem ber of Euclid Christian Church.! He is survived by a number of j nieces and nephews. Funeral services were con- j ducted at 2 p.m. Saturday at Whitten Funeral Home by the j Rev. Herbert Moore. Burial took place in Presbyterian Ce- metery.

Scoring for the AU Stars were Terry Woods with 7, Ronnie Robinson with 7, John Thurman with 4, and Steve Cobb, Bryan Roach, and Dwayne Scruggs, aU with 2. document.text: The eleventh annual reunion of the old Confederates who fought under Col. John S. Mosby was held at Ber- ryville, near which place during the war Mosbys men made many daring exploits. The meeting was presided over by Col. Joseph Bryan, of Rich mond. Hon. Marshall McCormick de livered the address of welcome and a memorial from the pen of Col. John Alexander, of Leesburg, on the death of Chaplain Sidney Ferguson was read. J. William Foster was elected president and H. S. Ashby adjutant. The reunion closed tonight with an entertainment by Polk Miller and his Old South Quartet. At its regular meeting Garland Rodes Camp, Sons of Veterans, of Lynchburg, selected as their sponsor for the coming Confederate reunion Miss Rebecca Martin and as maid of honor Miss Norvie Craighill. both of that city. The Veterans have invited ex-Gov. Francis T. Nichols, who is spending the summer at Chase City, to attend the reunion and be one of the speakers. _ A call was issued by George E. Caskie, chairman of the executive committee of the Virginia Sunday- School Association, for the-State con vention to be held at Lynchburg Oc tober 3 to 5 . A large number of local committees will go to work at once arid arrange for a large attend ance. The last State convention was hqld at Petersburg in March, 1902.   George W. Wilson, of Fancy Hill, Rockbridge county, aged 73 years, is dead. He was a descendant of the Wilsons of Tinkling Springs, Augusta county, and had traveled over the whole of the United States. James Norton, of Medford,_ Mass., has discovered what he claimi to be the richest nickel mine in the United States on the edge of Floyd county, 10 miles south o f ShaWsville, on the Norfolk and Western railway. The lead is said to be large and Mr. Norton has ordered machinery for de veloping the property. The find is- lo cated four miles from the property of the United States Arsenic Mines Com pany, which is being operated by Pittsburg capitalists. The City Engineer, of Roanoke, is sued a building permit to the Norfolk and Western Railway for the erection of a new passenger station in that city at an estimated cost of 99,000. The Roanoke City Council enacted a Pure Food and Milk law. A drastic anti-gambling ordinance just enacted by the Roanoke City Council provides for a fine of not less than 50 nor more than 500 fot gaming. Mayor Cutchin says that he will permit no games of chance at the Roanoke fair in September. Mayor Joel H. Cutchin, of Roanoke, who was recently re-elected, in an in terview said he had given his time, attention and very best efforts to the city for two years and that his poli tical opponents have made the posi tion as unpleasant as possible. The Council, he says, has continually fought him in everything he attempts to do in the interest of the city, and recent proceedings he fears is an in dication that the same tactics will con tinue in the new Council. If so, he cannot and will not stand it. Some whom he thought were. his friends have shown an animosity that does not please him. He says the salary, which is less than any officer, police man or blacksmith of the city, is no compensation for the duties he is called upon to perform, to say nothing of a continual wrangle with the Coun cil, which is annoying to him and humiliating and distasteful to his rela tives and family. The Mayor says that the office has destroyed his law business and the continued harassing has injured his health and peace of mind. He says that if present condi tions continue no gentleman can- or will be Mayor of Roanoke. W. E. Ehoflf, 26 years old, is under arrest at Newport News on the charge of housebreaking, committed nearly six years ago. Ehoff was then living with his parents in Newport News. When he learned that a warrant had been sworn out against him he went to Philadelphia. While living there he was married, and a few days ago reappeared in Newport News with two children. The celebrated suit for divorce of Mrs. Olivia Thurman from her hus band, Gen. Charles Thurman, a rich landowner of Clarke county, which has been before the public frequently during the last year, was settled out of court. A decree will be entered giving Mrs. Thurman a divorce a mens et thoro, which will become absolute in three years, when alimony will cease. Caroline County Camp of Confed erate Veterans has decided to raise 2,500 for the erection of a monument to the Confederate soldiers of that county who were killed or died in the service. Rev. A. C. Knibb. a ministerial stu dent at the Virginia Christian Colege, of Lynchburg, has been conducting a protracted meeting in a tent in West Lynchburg for six weeks and nearly 300 persons have professed conver sion. About 200 persons have been baptized and many others will receive the ordinance-in a day or two. A broken axle wrecked n ears of a freight train on the Atlantic Coast line near Emnoria. No one was hurt. Mrs. R. L. Pownell, of Sherman dis trict. near Romney, was badly scald ed in the face while boiling hops. Miss Elizabeth Booker, of Lynch burg. who was injured in a runaway a- nt, has recovered consciousness after Iving in a comatose condition for more than 75 hours.

document.text: Thanks for a copy of a recent is sue of The Communicator, public- cation of U. S. NCS, GUAM . We reprint the following  Early this week Emile Thurman Bruce, CS B, USNR F-6, brought to a close 20 years before the mast. He was transferred to the Fleet Reserve- The 44 year old Commissaryman hadnt intended to stay so long . . World War II chang ed his mind for him. When bombs thudded into Ford Island on Dec. 7, 1941, Emile was working as a butcher in the galley there. For the past ten months he has been at Radio Barrigada where he worked as a cook. He spent a total of eight years in destroyer service. I didnt plan to go for 20 years when I came in. In 1941, just a year after I was to have been paid off for the last time, the Japanese attacked the Naval Air Station, Pearl Harbor. I was working in the galley there at the time. We took a bomb between the dispensary and the chow hall. Before long they were using the mess tables as hos pital beds for the wounded. Now, Im going to take 90 days rest and have my wife bring in coffee to me every morning on a tray, said Emile with a smile. Then Im go ing to get a job that will keep me close to home. O f all the duty 1 have had, I guess I like destroyers best. When I was single I think that sea duty was the best duty I could think of having . . if you except that picket duty of Okinawa, when we were attacked by Kamakazi. Id prefer any man-o-war, though. Bruces wife is from historic Appo mattox, Va- His mother is Mrs. Eva B. Snowden of Port Royal, Va. The Bruce family contains Emile Reba Bruce, 6 Bonny Eloise, 4 and Milton Thurman, 7 months. The last Bruce mentioned is the one Emile hasnt seen yet. He will remedy that soon. His awards include Good Conduct, American Defense, Amer ican Theater, Philippine Liberation two stars, W W II Victory, Asia tic - Pacific 4 stars, Navy Occu pation one star.

He hung out his shingle in 1903, having graduated from Medical College of Virginia, Richmond, just before the turn of the century. His internship was at a Winston-Salem, N .C . hospital and his first practice inKentueky. He heard of a need ot a doctor in Pam plin, population 400. He acquired his first automobile, a Model T , in 1918. Before that he rode horseback. He liked spirited horses. His wife, the former A Hie Thornton, knew his favorite food, stewed apples. And I recall Dr. Lukin a a great baseball fan. Seldom missed a home game of the Appomattox Green Sox. What a man! Successful doctor and successful druggist. Buckles, Mattie Thornton, Mrs. Woodrow Williams, Lewis Car- Well, M rs. Osie Southall, and son, W iley. Thanks for the memory, thanks for the gift of this oid paper, and thanks to you for reading. document.text: Statesmanship in the Vocative. It is to be supposed that there is as much brains m the United States to-day as there ever was before. Aud yet it seems that there has never been a time in our history when there were a few men in pub lic life who rise above their fellows as at the present. Meu who are en gaged iu the affairs of government, or who are ordinarily spoken of as candidates for high office, seem to be almost on a dead level of mediocrity. In neither house of Congress s there a man who is regarded as a leader and a statesman above his fel lows. Senator Hoar is a man of abil- ty, doubtless, but he had iu recent years shown more of a ctpacity to be led than to lead. Sen-itor llauna is the most influential man in the Sen- ite, but not by virtue of statesman hip. He possesses none of the quail ies which made the great Senators of the ante-bellum period leaders, and none of the brilliance of the la ter Eepublicans, such as Oliver P. Morton, Conkling and Blaine. With the death of Hendricks, Thurman, Bayard, and the retirement from public life of Mr. John G. Carlisle, the Democratic party has been much iu the same plight. When one be gins to discuss party candidates for the Presidency in 1904 no one is able to mention a tolerably available man in either party whose name is famil iar to all the people as were the names of Hendricks, Bayard or Conkling. The name of Mr. Thom as B. Heed is familiar enough, but he is not keeping step with his party, and he does not possess the knack of catching step which Senator Hoar so eminently possesses. When Mr. Heed and Mr. William L. Wilson re tired from the House of Repre sentatives, there were no Elishas in their respective parties upon whom they could drop their mantles. It may be that the best statesmen we possess find it impossible to adjust their views to party policies. In the old days this was not necessary, as the party policies were formulat ed by the statesmen themselves and not by the mere politicians. It may he that the best talent of the country is not available for the United States Government because of the superior inducements offered by the great corporations or by the rewards of labor in other walks of private life. Whatever the reason may be the fact is to be deplored.Baito. Sun.

document.text: so unselfishly gave. The staff at the American Cancer Society office and Mr. Thurman for their concern and help. The many clubs and organizations that so willingly pitched in and gave the many prayer services that were held for Kenneth the bloodmobiles that were held for him the Metropolitan Ambu lance Service, who day in and day out took such good care of Kenneth en route to and from Charlottesville. A special thanks to Mr. Kimball Glass and his crew whom we saw night and day in the last week of my sons life. It is people, like these ip our communities that makes this a place to be proud of and not to knock it, but to be thankful that we are part of it. Because there are many such children as my son out there who will continue to need your help until one day God will give the knowledge of a cure for this terrible disease called Cancer we thank God for each and every one of you. The family of Kenneth Craig Scott by his mother, Thelma Scott Racey

document.text: Sawdust Saving Worth Millions of Dollars Nèw York.By making thinner saws, which will save as little as one- sixteenth of an Inch In the width ot cuts made In wood, an annual watte of sawdust amounting to more than  00 , 000,000 may be saved for the American lumber Industry. This report was made recently to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers by a special research com mittee on saws and knives. Efficient standardisation of saws, the committee said, might accomplish the saving. document.text: Richmond, Va., May 7.- The 115 organizations that lend their support in the safety crusade of the Vir ginia State-Wide Safety Conference are distributing thousands of pro grams of the 18th annual meeting to be held here May 15-17 in the Jefferson Hotel, Col. Wm. M. Myers, executive secretary of the conference said today. With the program, that includes over 150 speakers on all phases of safety, Governor John S. Battle, the general chairman, sends an open let ter to the people of Virginia in which he says, The rate of acci dents in Virginia, including those on our streets and highways, in our homes and factories, and in all phases of our daily activities, can be reduced if the people are given proper information on preventative measures and resolve to apply it in telligently. We have a splendid state-wide organization which is ac tively at work in this important field. This is the Virginia State-Wide Safe ty Conference, which has one ob jectiveto make Virginia a safer place in which to liv e ....I urge you to attend and take part in the 18th annual meeting of safety lead ers and delegates in Richmond May 19-171, 1952. A new federal safety .section, headed by Rear Admiral D.H.Clarke, UiSN, Commandant of the Norfolk Naval Shipyard, has been added and will deal with safety problems of the U. S. Government employers, Col Myers added. General session speakers an nounced by Don N. Frazier, general program chairman include Ralph L. Lee, of Detroit Thurman Sensing, of Nashville, Tenn., and J. Dewey Dorsett, of Ridgewood, N. J. The Conference will be opened by an address of Governor Battle. Mayor T. Nelson Parker will give the welcome to Richmond. The housing chairman reports that early reservations are heavy and an all time record of attendance is ex pected.

Survivors, besides his moth er, include three b r o t h e r s , Charles Blackwell, Lawrence Jones and Thurman Jones, all I of Appomattox and a sister, Mrs. Katie Walker of Detroit, Mich. Funeral services were con ducted at 2 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 4 at the Mt. Airy Baptist Church by the Rev. H. W. Pryor. Burial took place in the family ceme tery. Oak church attending the mission study class held last Wednesday at the home of Mrs. Curry Abbitt were Mrs. E. J. Marsh, Mrs. Clarence Adams, Mrs. C. D. Lewis, Mrs. Jim Childers, Mrs. Harry Harris, Mrs. LeRoy Marks, Mrs. Harry Lucado, and Mrs. Dick Smith. It ,was a most enjoyable day for everyone. Mr. and Mrs. White Lucoda, Lila and Thurman Wilcox, and ,Mary Bass leave today for Ohio. They are go ing to see Mrs. Lucados mother, who is to return with them at the end of this week.

document.text: November 13 - Farmers were glad of the tobacco season last week. George Kress returned home from the hospital on Monday. Mrs. Kenneth Richardson had surgery at Virginia Baptist Hospital last week. A speedy recovery is wished her. Rev. A. M. Taylor was called back to D avenport, Iowa because of the illness of his daughter-in-laws brother who was undergoing an operation last week. Mrs. Helen Inge and Mrs. Louise Roach attended a council meeting at Brookneal church on Wednesday. Sympathy is extended the McDowell family of Brookneal. Rev. W. H. Elder attended the funeral at Falling River Church on Wednesday. Mr, and Mrs. Kenneth SC John returned from Canada oh Wednesday afternoon after a most delightful trip to see their eon, Dennis and family. M rs. M argaret M arshall returned to the home óf her son Jimmie near Oakville on Sunday. Rev. A. M. Taylor, Helen Inge, Louise Roach and Ruby Almond will attend the General Association in-toanipke on Tuesday. Rev. Jerry Lethco was visiting in the neighborhood last Monday while in a revival at Rustburg last week. Rev. and Mrs. W. H. Elder attended the funeral, of Mrs. Doc Franklin at Hollywood Church Sunday afternoon. A very large crowd was there. Ronnie Richardson returned from a week in Kansas City, Mo. after a most delightful trip. Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Ranson spent Saturday night in Roanoke with Mr. and Mrs. Thurman Wilcox. document.text: NOV. 11 - Has November ever had more lovelier days than we have had so far. If many leaves make a hard winter, we have it. Trooper W. R. Roach has returned from a hunting trip to I Montana. Katherine Dickerson left last Tuesday on a trip to Hawaii. Rev. Don Wagner went to Winston-Salem, N.C. Tuesday for the day. Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Ran son and Mr. and Mrs. Thurman Wilcox left Saturday for Kings port, Tenn., to visit Mr. and Mrs. Strode Burks over the  week end. Sympathy is extended Mrs. Patsy Richardson in the death of her aunt, Mrs. Emma Reynolds of Appomattox, on Saturday night. Mrs. James Thackston of High Point, N.C. is visiting her mother, Mrs. Maude Ranson and sister, Mrs. Pearl Wilson. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Farrar and Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Coleman left Friday to visit Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Allen and Mr. 1 and Mrs. Max Duffey, of Fairfax, over the week end. The R. A. leaders, Thomas Ranson and Joe Almond ac-i companied by Bill Caldwell and Lloyd Richardson took a num ber of R.A. boys to Richmond Saturday. The Rocks Quartet furnished the bus for them to  go and Herman Richardson donated the gas. Mr. and Mrs. Allen James of Winston-Salem, N.C., attended services at Rocks Church Sunday and were guests of Rev. and Mrs. Don Wagner and Gary. Dont forget the Foreign Mission Study at Elon Church on Thursday night at 730 p.m. Sunday is high attendance goal at Rocks. Wont you plan to help reach it and go over, if possible. Rev. Don Wagner will attend the State General Association in Roanoke this week. The Rocks Quartet went to Providence Church Sunday night to sing.

document.text: N ot U nlikely th a t Senator D an iel W ill B e Offered the P lace. The Richmond Times Washington correspondence Monday, says The question of the successorship to Judge Bond is one which is receiving a consideration in Virginia which has been unparalleled within the history of the State for the number of good men who are absolutely seek ing the office rather than the office seeking them. This is not the fact with the men whose names I have or will mention, as they are men whose friends and acquaintances have un- stintingly recommended them, inde pendent of theirown preferences in the matter. Virginia is the only onb of the States comprising the district, save that of South Carolina, which has not now a flattering representation in the federal judiciary, and conse quently it would seem within the bounds of legitimate reason that Mr Cleveland would well consider the candidacy of its meritorious citizens. In South Carolina the state of affairs is such that the President would hardly dare make an appointment without feeling assured that he an tagonized some element of Democ racy, and thus in our Commonwealth alone does he find a number of capa ble eligible and worthy men, which from their standpoint would natur ally be the subject of his considera tion. The story that Mr. Clevelands former desires to appoint Judge Keith, of Warren ton, asohief justice of the District Court, is fresh in the minds of all of our people, and the fact that his commission, already made out, was withheld only at the personal request of Judge Thurman, who was his partner upon the national ticket, warrants, at least, the assumption that now the judge may receive his most favorable inves tigation. It is reported today that Senator Ransom, of North Carolina, is a candidate for this position, and his recent action in the Senate may have some tendency to impress upon the President his claims, yet the fact remains that Senator Ransom has not been in active practice for more than twenty years, and indulging, as he has continuously, in the details of politics, he has detracted very much from what years ago would have been a formidable application. The two latest aspirants for the office are said to be Judge S. G. Whittle of Henry county, and Judge Berryman Green, of Danville, both of whom are gentlemen well equipped for the place in question. However, they will hardly be considered by the President in advance of Con gressman Tucker, the Hon. C. V. Meredith, of Richmond, or others whose claims have already been pre sented. Beyond all of this there may be possibly a surprise in store for the people of Virginia, growing out of the fact that Mr. Cleveland has always proven a man of surprises. The average guesser would hardly suppose that Senator John W. Dan iel would be selected for a place like this, owing especially to the fact that he led the opposition to Mr. Cleveland in the State campaign of 1892, and during the recent debate in the Senate he has preferred to ally himself with the interests which were most pronounced to the panacea propounded by the President. Yet the appointment of ex-Senator Eustis  of Louisana, to the Court of St. Jamees was no more of surprise than ! that which would be created by the appointment of Senator Daniel, and j yet Mr. Cleveland named him for ! that important post. The adminis- ! tration has already signified to some of the callers that the candidacy of Major Holmes Conrad and General Lee for the United States Senate was equally agreeable to the President, and that he would aid them as far as possible The appointment of Sen ator Daniel will leave, of course, an opportunity for both of these gentle men to come into the United States Senate, and while it is assured that I one of these places will be captured by either General Hunton or Hon. j Thomas S. Martin, of Scottsville, it is possible that Mr. Cleveland would j prefer to have any of the allies in

She was reared near Bent Crook in Appomattox, and moved to Washington, D.C., in her Into teens. A fter  working in Washington for ID years, she returned to Appomattox in 1945 to cu e for her father and er, who had taken ill. While caring for her father and grandmother, she began baking tarts and pies, which were sold in Appomattox at Gobeis Service Station and Mrs. Reynolds Grocery Store. Response to her baked goods was, so good that she opened a small restaurant in December at 1946. a couple at miles east of the town of Appomattox on Route 460. Four years later, in i960, Maude moved her restaurant to a new building on west of the town at Appomattox on Route 460.
